title: 010 Espresso simple UI test
UI testing tools

inline_content.Text: UI testing tools

title: Two main tools that are nowadays mostly used for UI testing are Appium and Espresso.

inline_content.Text: Two main tools that are nowadays mostly used for UI testing are Appium and Espresso.

title: | Appium | Espresso | | —— | —— | | blackbox test | white/gray box testing | |what you see is what you can test|can change inner workings of the app and prepare it for testing, e.g. save some data to database or sharedpreferences before running the test| |used mostly for integration end to end tests and entire user flows|testing the functionality of a screen and/or flow| |can be abstracted so test written can be executed on iOS and Android| Android Only |well supported|well supported| |supports parallel testing on multiple devices with selenium grid| Not out of the box parallel testing, plugins like Spoon exists until true Google support comes out

inline_content.Text: | Appium | Espresso | | —— | —— | | blackbox test | white/gray box testing | |what you see is what you can test|can change inner workings of the app and prepare it for testing, e.g. save some data to database or sharedpreferences before running the test| |used mostly for integration end to end tests and entire user flows|testing the functionality of a screen and/or flow| |can be abstracted so test written can be executed on iOS and Android| Android Only |well supported|well supported| |supports parallel testing on multiple devices with selenium grid| Not out of the box parallel testing, plugins like Spoon exists until true Google support comes out

title: NOTE

If you are using latest support libraries, annotations etc. you need to exclude the older versions from espresso to avoid collisions:

inline_content.Text: NOTE
If you are using latest support libraries, annotations etc. you need to exclude the older versions from espresso to avoid collisions:

title: Other than these imports it is necessary to add android instrumentation test runner to build.gradle android.defaultConfig:

inline_content.Text: Other than these imports it is necessary to add android instrumentation test runner to build.gradle android.defaultConfig:

title: testInstrumentationRunner "android.support.test.runner.AndroidJUnitRunner"
Device setup

inline_content.Text: Device setup

title: For non flaky test it is recommended to set following settings on your devices:

inline_content.Text: For non flaky test it is recommended to set following settings on your devices:

title: Developer options / Disable Animations - reduces flakyness of tests

inline_content.Text: Developer options / Disable Animations - reduces flakyness of tests

title: Developer options / Stay awake - if you have dedicated devices for tests this is usefull

inline_content.Text: Developer options / Stay awake - if you have dedicated devices for tests this is usefull

title: Developer options / Logger buffer sizes - set to higher number if you run very big test suites on your phone

inline_content.Text: Developer options / Logger buffer sizes - set to higher number if you run very big test suites on your phone

title: Accessibility / Touch & Hold delay - long to avoid problems with tapping in espresso

inline_content.Text: Accessibility / Touch & Hold delay - long to avoid problems with tapping in espresso

title: Quite a setup from the real world ha? Well now when thats out of the way lets take a look how to setup a small test

inline_content.Text: Quite a setup from the real world ha? Well now when thats out of the way lets take a look how to setup a small test

title: Writing the test

inline_content.Text: Writing the test

title: Lets assume that we have the following screen:
The screen contains:

inline_content.Text: Lets assume that we have the following screen:
The screen contains:

title: text input field -
R.id.textEntry
b

inline_content.Text: text input field -
R.id.textEntry

title: button which shows snackbar with typed text when clicked -
R.id.shownSnackbarBtn
b

inline_content.Text: button which shows snackbar with typed text when clicked -
R.id.shownSnackbarBtn

title: snackbar which should contain user typed text -
android.support.design.R.id.snackbar_text
b

inline_content.Text: snackbar which should contain user typed text -
android.support.design.R.id.snackbar_text

title: Now lets create a class that will test our flow:

inline_content.Text: Now lets create a class that will test our flow:

title: As you noticed there are 3-4 things that you might notice come often:

inline_content.Text: As you noticed there are 3-4 things that you might notice come often:

title: onView(withXYZ)
b
<– viewMatchers with them you are able to find elements on screen

inline_content.Text: onView(withXYZ)
<– viewMatchers with them you are able to find elements on screen

title: perform(click())
b
<– viewActions, you can execute actions on elements you previously found

inline_content.Text: perform(click())
<– viewActions, you can execute actions on elements you previously found

title: check(matches(isDisplayed()))
b
<– viewAssertions, checks you want to do on screens you previously found

inline_content.Text: check(matches(isDisplayed()))
<– viewAssertions, checks you want to do on screens you previously found

title: All of these and many others can be found here: https://google.github.io/android-testing-support-library/docs/espresso/cheatsheet/index.html

inline_content.Text: All of these and many others can be found here: https://google.github.io/android-testing-support-library/docs/espresso/cheatsheet/index.html

title: Thats it, now you can run the test either with right clicking on the class name / test and selecting Run test or with command:

inline_content.Text: Thats it, now you can run the test either with right clicking on the class name / test and selecting Run test or with command:

title: ./gradlew connectedFLAVORNAMEAndroidTest
